text: hi everyone my name is Adam GATT
I'm a senior specialist solution
architect for analytics at AWS
in this video
I'll explain the Amazon redshift
automated materialize view feature and
give a short demo to show how it can
improve the performance of analytic
queries and dashboards
first I'll explain at a high level what
materialized views are
a materialized view is a database object
that stores pre-computed query results
and a materialized in other words
persisted data set
similar queries can use the pre-computed
results from the materialized view and
skip the expensive tasks of reading the
underlying tables and Performing joins
and Aggregates therefore improving the
query performance
materialized views are not just a simple
cache however
when data changes are applied on the
underlying tables
materialized views can be refreshed
either automatically or manually
with a full or incremental refresh
and they can be used by other similar
queries not just the query used to
create the materialized view
also with the query rewrite feature user
queries on base tables can be
automatically and transparently
Rewritten by the database engine to use
one or more materialized views
improving the performance of dashboards
and queries without the user even
needing to be aware the materialized
views exist
with the automated materialized view
feature or Auto MV for short
Amazon richer monitors user queries and
using machine learning algorithms
calculates the benefit of creating one
or more Auto and these to improve the
performance of the query and similar
queries
versus the cost of system resources
required to create and maintain the
autoimvs
if Amazon redshift determines the
expected performance Improvement of
creating automobiles is worth the cost
it automatically creates them in the
background and then uses the query
rewrite feature to redirect user queries
to them
when data is changed on the underlying
tables
Amazon redshift runs an incremental
refresh which automatically updates the
autoimvs by inserting updating and
deleting any change rows
Amazon redshift then monitors the
Automobiles and drops any that are no
longer used or can't be refreshed due to
the underlying table's structure
changing
now I'll demonstrate the automated
materialized view high level process
flow with an animation
when users run queries that aggregate
data with group buys
Amazon redshift monitors the queries and
applies machine learning algorithms to
evaluate the benefit of creating an
automobile in terms of the estimated
performance gain versus the cost and
system resources to create and maintain
the auto MV
if Amazon redshift determines the
estimated performance gain is worth the
cost
it automatically creates one or more
materialized views in the background
now when users run the same or similar
queries again
the queries are Rewritten by Amazon
redshift to read data from the auto
materialized views instead of the base
tables this process is completely
transparent to the user
the pre-computed results from the auto
mvs are then returned to the user
as the expense of processing tasks of
scanning the base tables joining the
data and Performing the Aggregates don't
need to be executed again
the performance of the query is improved
when data is modified on the base tables
with insert update or delete statements
the auto mvs are incrementally updated
automatically when there are spare
Cycles on the cluster
finally Amazon redshift continues to
monitor queries and if some or all of
the auto mvs are not used for some time
or if they can't be refreshed possibly
due to the structure of the base tables
changing
then the unused autoimvs are dropped and
the resources are released
now I'll demonstrate a real working
example of autoimvs improving the
performance of a quick site dashboard
this is a sales order dashboard based on
a tpch data set it's using a live
connection to a redshift cluster
the cluster currently has no Auto and
V's on it and I've also turned off the
results cache
if I change filters on the dashboard
you can see it's taking approximately 10
to 20 seconds for the visuals on the
dashboard to refresh
each of the windows
is running a separate query on the
cluster
in the reach of console
I can see the queries that have been run
by the Dashboard
each group of four queries
is One dashboard refresh
and I can see they've taken between 8
and 13 seconds
if I look at the query plan
I can see the exact steps redshift has
taken to process the query
it looks complex but it's just showing
what processing redshift has done
to run the query
you can see the tables
that have been read these are the base
tables
and the join operations
and the aggregate operation
I'll now pause this recording
and come back after a period of time to
allow redshift to create the autoimvs
during this time
Richard will run its machine learning
algorithms over the queries that I've
run
and will automatically create one or
more Auto and these in the background
yeah
I'm now back after allowing time for
redshift to create the autoimvs
if I change the filters on the dashboard
now
you can see it as refreshing much more
quickly
if I look into the query console
I can see the last refresh took between
224 milliseconds and 249 milliseconds
if I look at the query plan
you can see the query has been Rewritten
and is now using the autoimvs and not
the base tables
for further information on automated
materialized views
please view the redshift developer guide
also if you're interested in a deep dive
into the inner workings of Auto mvs and
the results of some AWS performance
tests
please look into the blog post
optimize your Amazon redshift query
performance with automated materialized
views
thank you for watching
